abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for Sergipe Rural Poverty
            Reduction Project in Brazil were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was low or
            negligible, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            borrower performance was satisfactory. Lessons learned were
            as follows: 1) the differentiation of municipalities and
            resource allocations based on United Nations human
            development index (HDI) makes strategic and practical sense
            but requires commitment to the principal and close
            monitoring; 2) Community-driven development (CDD) is
            evolving from pure demand to tied demand with investments
            consistent with government's poverty
            policies/strategies and HDI-based poverty status; 3) CDD
            mechanisms can improve the quality/targeting of non-project
            resources while leveraging complementary funding and
            intensifying poverty reduction efforts; 4) Political, legal
            and bureaucratic impediments to implementation require
            patient, skilled mitigation by the project supervision team;
            5) Indicative annual budgets for Municipal Councils improve
            planning and build confidence in the program; 6) Systematic
            impact evaluation remains elusive; and 7) CDD can
            effectively target poor rural women.
